awd_titl_txt: Set-theoretic methods and the study of compact spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates fundamental and foundational questions in connection with convergence or limiting properties of infinite sets in an ambient space. The issues of the long-term behavior of an infinite sequence of processes or systems (however abstract) is at the core of many mathematical or physical questions. The universal setting for this investigation is known as the study of compact topological spaces. The "points" in the ambient space can represent any mathematical object in applications ranging from turbulent dynamical systems to a quantum mechanics setting. It has emerged that many natural questions are sensitive to the very foundational principles of mathematics itself. This research project pursues the resolution of such topological questions armed with the modern methods of uncovering possible dependence on the foundational axioms of mathematics. 

The investigator will  study the influence of well-known countability properties on the structure of compact (Hausdorff)  spaces. Some spaces are determined by the behavior of their converging   sequences, while one of the most fundamental  spaces, henceforth  BetaN, the Stone-Cech compactification of the integers N,  are at the opposite extreme in that it has no converging sequences whatsoever. The behavior of BetaN is heavily influenced by extra axioms of set-theory  and  many natural questions about spaces of functions and measures and the like,  are as well. Additionally, the Banach spaces of continuous real-valued functions with domain some compact subset of BetaN  will be investigated. Again set-theoretic hypotheses, mixed with additional topological properties, lead to varying behavior in the important class of compact spaces. Our study is the  analysis of the interplay between the various  countable convergence conditions and the axioms of set-theory that influence them.  We are expecting to have to develop new techniques of constructing topological spaces as well as the refinement of forcing techniques to uncover basic combinatorial structures involved. These specific problems of longstanding will  be of central focus. (1) If an infinite compact space has no converging sequence, does it contain a copy of BetaN? (2) Are the metrizable compact spaces the only ones whose diagonal is uncountably-inaccessible? (3) Is the Banach space of continuous functions on the remainder BetaN - N, like  BetaN - N itself, essentially unique in certain models of set theory? (4) If the topology of a compact space is determined by converging countable sequences, is there a finite or countable bound on how many times one must iterate taking limits to capture all such limits?

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the project were to utilize and extend set-theoretic methods (foundational assumptions of mathematics) to achieve a greater understanding of the sometimes intricate nature of infinitary convergence in topological spaces. Modern set-theory facilitates the meaningful study of many extended notions of infinity. The best known of these is the familiar counting infinity of the set of all positive integers while the infinitude of the set of irrational numbers is provably, and famously, greater. Nevertheless, while the reach of the countable notion of inifinite is profound in mathematics, it is of fundamental importance to uncover its limitations. A major component of this project was to explore when such limitations in certain key settings are sensitive to the foundational assumptions of the (entire) mathematical universe under study.  Modern set-theory has formalized, and made possible rigorous study, the notion of many universes and established their necessity.

Many especially impactful extra `axioms' of set-theory, such as the continuum hypothesis and Martin's Axiom, are used to focus on universes in which these hold or fail. This project was successful in establishing that a 50 year old question about countable convergence, known as the Moore-Mrowka problem, was not decided by either of these two particular axioms. For example, while the problem was known to have a negative answer in some universes satisfying the continuum hypothesis, we established that there are others in which it had a positive answer. The longer term impact of the project is expected to be that the techniques developed in establishing the results will extend to other problems and settings.
